title: FirstFT: US launches security pact to challenge China
text:
The US has launched a new trilateral security partnership with the UK and Australia that will enable Canberra to build a fleet of nuclear-powered submarines, a move that will strengthen the allies' ability to counter China.

President Joe Biden announced the effort, which is designed to bolster alliances amid rising tensions with Beijing over disputes ranging from the South China Sea to Taiwan, in a virtual event yesterday with British prime minister Boris Johnson and his Australian counterpart Scott Morrison.

Biden said the initiative was necessary to ensure the countries had the best technology to “defend against rapidly evolving threats”, in rhetoric that appeared to be aimed at Beijing.

Morrison said it was a “forever partnership . . . between the oldest and most trusted of friends”. The pact, also known as AUSUK, “represents a substantial capability leap for the Royal Australian Navy”, the Australian government said. Read more on how the agreement will allow Australia to project power across the western Pacific.

The Chinese embassy in Washington denounced the move. “They should shake off their cold war mentality and ideological prejudice,” said Liu Pengyu, the embassy spokesperson. 

But US allies in the region welcomed the new agreement. Officials in Taipei, which is on the frontline of tensions between Washington and Beijing, said the alliance would help balance China's growing military strength and assertiveness.

“The creation of AUKUS fills the most important gap in the security web of the entire western Pacific,” said one Taiwanese official.

Taro Kono, a former Japanese foreign and defence minister and a leading candidate to succeed Yoshihide Suga as prime minister, said: “We very much welcome that the UK is once again turning its eyes to the Pacific region.”

As part of the pact, Australia will scrap a programme to buy 12 conventional submarines from France that was signed in 2016. Instead it will procure at least eight nuclear-powered submarines, which are faster, quieter and can operate over longer ranges.

France reacted with fury at Canberra's decision to cancel the $90bn deal with Paris. “This decision is contrary to the letter and spirit of the co-operation that prevailed between France and Australia,” said Jean-Yves Le Drian, French foreign minister, and defence minister Florence Parly.

What are your thoughts? Do you think China poses a military threat in the Asia-Pacific region? Email me at gordon.smith@ft.com. Thanks for reading and here's the rest of today's news — Gordon

Five more stories in the news

1. Goldman to buy speciality lender GreenSky The Wall Street investment bank has agreed to buy online loans provider GreenSky for $2.2bn as it continues to build its presence in consumer lending. It is Goldman's second multibillion-dollar acquisition in under a month and highlights chief executive David Solomon's intention to transform the investment bank into a more consumer-focused financial institution. 

2. Biden-backed drug pricing proposal hits hurdle Joe Biden's hopes of securing legislation that would allow the US government to negotiate lower drug prices for seniors was dealt a blow yesterday. Three moderate members of the president's party on the House energy and commerce committee voted against the measure, scuppering the bill and handing a significant victory to pharmaceutical companies.

3. Dalio warns regulators could ‘kill' bitcoin Ray Dalio, the founder of Bridgewater Associates, said regulators would shut down bitcoin if the cryptocurrency became too successful and dismissed predictions by Ark Invest's Cathie Wood that its price would increase tenfold within five years. Do you agree with Wood's prediction? Vote in our poll.

4. US envoy: Ghani's escape derailed last-ditch Taliban deal Afghan president Ashraf Ghani's decision to flee the country last month scuppered a last-minute deal with the Taliban designed to keep Kabul out of the Islamists' hands and negotiate a political transition, the US diplomat in charge of talks with the Taliban has said.

5. Macau's casino stocks shed $20bn The Macau government yesterday opened a 45-day public consultation on revising its gaming law, wiping more than $20bn off the market value of listed gambling operators. The news had a knock-on impact on shares in many of the groups' US parents, including MGM Resorts International and Las Vegas Sands.

Coronavirus digest

  • Pfizer and Moderna said that protection from their vaccines could wane over time, as the US drug regulator prepared to consider whether to approve a booster programme.

  • Los Angeles county is set to broaden its proof of Covid-19 vaccination requirements for indoor venues such as bars and nightclubs and outdoor “mega events” such as concerts and sporting matches.

  • China's economic slowdown worsened in August as outbreaks exposed lingering weakness in consumer spending.

  • Vaccinated travellers will no longer need to take a Covid-19 test before entering England, ministers will announce later this week.

The day ahead

Data Retail sales data for August is expected to be released and is likely to show a fall to 0.8 per cent compared to July. Initial claims for state unemployment benefits for the week ended September 11 are also due to be released.

Company events Ford is expected to make an electric vehicle announcement. Yesterday self-driving start-up Argo AI revealed plans for an autonomous vehicle delivery service in Miami, Austin, and Washington DC, in partnership with Ford and Walmart. (Reuters)

Macron-Merkel Elysée Palace dinner France's President Emmanuel Macron and Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel will meet today to discuss EU policy and Afghanistan.

Shanghai Co-operation Organisation annual summit Foreign ministers from China, Russia, Iran and Pakistan will meet in the Tajikistan capital of Dushanbe. Virtual attendees, discussing how to deal with the new Taliban leadership in Kabul, include Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping. (Bloomberg)

What else we're reading and listening to

Russian elections: persecution and cash handouts The outcome of Sunday's elections for the Duma may be a foregone conclusion: United Russia is expected to retain its constitutional majority. But as soaring food prices and sliding real incomes have sent approval ratings to record lows, Vladimir Putin is pulling out all the stops to crack down on dissent.

Rise of sports betting fuels demand for data gatekeepers The legalisation of US sports betting is driving new demand for statistics on players, games, teams and performance. A pair of sports data companies have installed themselves as the gatekeepers to this information trove: Sportradar Group and Genius Sports. For more news on the business of sport sign-up to the Scoreboard email.

China's financial blogger crackdown Beijing has launched a clampdown on financial blogs and social media, a move that risks exacerbating a chronic problem plaguing the world's second-biggest economy: a dearth of reliable data.

Is Canada on the verge of a big political shift? Canadians go the polls on Monday. The snap election will be a verdict on Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's handling of the coronavirus pandemic. Ahead of the vote Gideon Rachman, chief foreign affairs columnist, is joined by Darrell Bricker, author of several books on Canadian politics, to discuss the election in this week's Rachman Review podcast.

Call to find America's fastest growing companies 2022 The FT, in partnership with Statista, is seeking to identify The Americas' 500 companies with the strongest revenue growth between 2017 and 2020. To apply for a place in the third annual FT ranking of companies in north, central and South America register here and to explore the current rankings go here.

Travel

Yasuto Kamoshita, co-founder of Japanese clothing brand United Arrows, shares his insider's guide to Tokyo. “A lot of the best stores are a mish-mash of different things, both classic and street, creating a scrambled style,” he writes.
